Case: Jeremy-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024
Client: Jeremy Lindsey

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Called client to get update on treatment.

Jeremy-only went to PCP but was not referred for any additional treatment. Still healing his leg lacerations

Elizabeth- had xray and MRI done with ortho doctors referred to PT with Aptiva Health. Going once a week.

Owen-had follow up at the hospital with trauma physicians. advised to avoid sports. Follow up on Jan 5

Chase- Had his neck brace removed but had pain and neck issue and found out to have broken collarbone. Follow up again on Jan 5. Possible psychological trauma. Will inform if client needs therapy. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Jessa
__Date & Time__: December 21 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on December 21, 2024 with Jeremy Lindsey regarding motor vehicle accident. Jessa called the client to obtain an update on treatment. Jeremy reported that he has only seen his primary care physician and was not referred for any additional treatment; he is still healing his leg lacerations.

Elizabeth had an x-ray and an MRI performed. Orthopedic doctors referred her to physical therapy with Aptiva Health, with sessions scheduled once a week.

Owen had a follow-up at the hospital with trauma physicians, who advised him to avoid sports. A follow-up is scheduled for January 5.

Chase had his neck brace removed but continues to experience pain and neck issues and was found to have a broken collarbone. A follow-up is planned for January 5. There is a possibility of psychological trauma; the team will inform if the client needs therapy.

Earlier, on February 21, 2025, Jennifer Howard replied that she had the matter on her calendar to review next Tuesday concerning settlement proposals for all involved parties, and that she would reach out then to discuss further. Her message included her title and contact information for Progressive Direct Insurance Company, along with a P.O. Box address in Cleveland, Ohio, and both her work and fax numbers.

Prior to that, on February 20, 2025 at 2:29 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote to Jennifer Howard and Jeremy Lindsey’s Filevine project address regarding Lindsey Family #24-902741838. In that message, he explained that there is a policy limits issue in the case because there are five injury claims in total. He stated that he represents four of the five claimants, all of whom are in the same family—a husband, wife, and their two kids. He indicated that if Progressive must preserve one of its two policy limits for some form of distribution to Dominic, Dominic would not be entitled to the other policy limit. Whaley asked Jennifer to tell him what the policy limits are so that they could determine a way to tender one of the limits to the Lindseys, and then wait on Dominic to decide what to do with the other one. The message included Whaley’s contact information and office address:
Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Case: Jeremy-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024. Client: Jeremy Lindsey. This note summarizes an external email thread concerning the Lindsey Family case number 24-902741838, in which Jeremy Lindsey is the client in a motor vehicle accident matter dated December 1, 2024.

The thread begins with an email dated February 20, 2025, from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (address: 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-583-4022; agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) to Jennifer Howard, a Senior Claims Specialist at Progressive Direct Insurance Company (PO Box 94670, Cleveland, OH 44101-9919; phone 859-629-4740; fax 833-905-1745; Jennifer_Howard@progressive.com), with Jeremy Lindsey copied to the Filevine project email address JeremyLindseyMVAZ4830966@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The subject of the message is “[EXTERNAL] Lindsey Family #24-902741838.” In this message, Whaley explained that there is a policy limits issue in the case because there are five total injury claims. He stated that he represents four of the five, all within the same family—a husband, a wife, and their two kids. He proposed preserving one of Progressive’s two policy limits for some distribution to Dominic, asserting that Dominic would not be entitled to the other policy limit. He asked Jennifer to provide the limits so they could determine a way to tender one of the limits to the Lindsey family and then wait for Dominic to decide what to do with the other limit. Whaley included his contact information again at the end of the message.

On February 21, 2025, Jennifer Howard replied. She acknowledged that she had this on her calendar to review the following Tuesday regarding settlement proposals for all involved parties and said she would reach out then to discuss further. Her signature identified her as Jennifer Howard, Claims Specialist-Sr., Progressive Direct Insurance Company, with the following contact details: PO Box 94670, Cleveland, OH 44101-9919; work phone 859-629-4740; fax 833-905-1745. The message was part of the same external thread concerning Lindsey Family #24-902741838.

A follow-up email from Aaron Whaley was sent on February 20, 2025 at 2:29 PM (in the thread, this is the original message that preceded Jennifer’s February 21 response). In that message, Whaley reiterated the policy-limits issue, clarified that he represents four of the five injuries within the same family (husband, wife, and their two kids), and discussed preserving one of Progressive’s two policy limits for distribution to Dominic. He stated that Dominic would not be entitled to the other policy limit and asked Jennifer to disclose the policy limits so they could tender one of them to the Lindseys and then await Dominic’s decision regarding the other limit. Whaley provided his contact information again.

The chain continues with a note on March 10, 2025, around 11:38 AM, from Aaron Whaley to Jennifer Howard (the exact phrasing in the header shows a request: “Jennifer, have you had a chance to take a look at this?”). This indicates a follow-up inquiry after Jennifer’s February 21 response, asking whether she had reviewed the matter.

Finally, on March 13, 2025, at 9:11:28 AM (GMT-04:00), Aaron Whaley sent a closing follow-up with the subject line “Circling back on this.” The email was again addressed to Jennifer Howard, with Jeremy Lindsey copied via the Filevine project email address. The message circulated the same firm contact details for Whaley Law Firm and reiterated the intent to follow up on the Lindsey Family matter. Whaley’s signature again lists the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222) and phone number (502-583-4022).

In summary, the note documents a back-and-forth with Progressive regarding how to handle policy limits across five injury claims within the Lindsey family, with Whaley representing four of the five claimants, the family structure (husband, wife, two kids), and Dominic as a potential recipient of one policy limit. The exchange includes three main responses: Whaley’s initial limits proposal on February 20, 2025; Jennifer Howard’s plan to review settlement proposals the following Tuesday (February 21, 2025); and subsequent follow-ups by Whaley on March 10 and March 13, 2025, seeking updates and circling back on the matter.

Case: Jeremy-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024
Client: Jeremy Lindsey

In the case of Jeremy Lindsey, arising from a motor vehicle accident on December 1, 2024 (Claim #24-902741838), the file shows a sequence of settlement and lien discussions during mid-April 2025. Beginning with a chain dated April 17, 2025, the parents of the passenger in the insured vehicle agreed to resolve their son’s bodily injury claim for $500, which would leave $45,500 of the $50,000 per-accident coverage to be divided among the Lindsey clients, with the instruction to provide a breakdown for each person so that no individual would receive more than the $25,000 per-person limit.

Later that same day, Jennifer Howard, a Claims Specialist-Senior at Progressive Direct Insurance Company, followed up to clarify and apologize for the earlier message. She explained that settlements are in exchange for a full release of all claims with indemnity and are inclusive of liens but exclusive of PIP. She noted that ERISA liens from Blue Cross and Blue Shield had been received on Jeremy, Chase, and Owen, and offered to email copies of those liens if requested. Her message confirmed that these liens must be addressed as part of the settlement process, and she identified the need for an affidavit regarding the children’s claims. Her contact details were Progressive Direct Insurance Company, PO Box 94670, Cleveland, OH 44101-9919, with a work phone of 859-629-4740 and a fax of 833-905-1745.

Earlier in the same thread, Aaron Whaley of the Whaley Law Firm replied to Jennifer. He thanked her for the update and clarification and requested that the ERISA liens be sent so affidavits could be prepared and the settlement breakdown confirmed soon. He asked for clarification as to whether she meant $49,500.

Jennifer responded again on April 17, 2025, clarifying her earlier statement. She reiterated that settlements were in exchange for a full release of all claims with indemnity and included liens, but were exclusive of PIP. She informed that ERISA liens had been received from Blue Cross and Blue Shield on Jeremy, Chase, and Owen and that she could email copies of the liens if desired. She also clarified that the plaintiffs in the matter referred to as “the parents of the passenger in our insured’s vehicle” had agreed to resolve their son’s bodily injury claim for $500, which would leave $45,500 out of the $50,000 per-accident coverage to be divided among the Lindsey clients, with the request to determine a breakdown where no one received more than the $25,000 per-person limit.

A subsequent message from Jennifer, sent at 5:39 PM on April 17, 2025, included a note of apology for having sent a prior message too soon. She reiterated that settlements require a full release of all claims with indemnity and are inclusive of liens but exclusive of PIP, and again confirmed the existence of ERISA liens from Blue Cross and Blue Shield on Jeremy, Chase, and Owen, offering to email those liens if requested.

That evening, at 7:24 PM, Aaron Whaley replied, acknowledging Jennifer’s notes and asking her to send the ERISA liens. He stated that affidavits would be prepared and that the settlement breakdown would be confirmed soon, and he again sought clarification on whether the amount was $49,500.

In the early hours of April 21, 2025, Jennifer replied that the amount left over for the clients was indeed $49,500, and she attached a letter confirming this figure along with copies of the liens she had received on the clients.

Finally, on April 21, 2025, at 11:02 AM, Aaron Whaley forwarded the exchange to Justin Chumbley and the Jeremy Lindsey Filevine project email address with a note that COOTS letters needed to be sent out on all of the Lindseys. The forwarding included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact information: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022. The message reflected the ongoing settlement and lien considerations surrounding Claim #24-902741838 in the Jeremy Lindsey MVA file.

episodes.natural_language:
In the file for the case Jeremy-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024, the client is Jeremy Lindsey. On July 9, 2025, an email chain about unpaid bills and reimbursements began with Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm writing to Jeremy Lindsey (addressed to jeremylindsey1978@yahoo.com) and copied Elizabeth Lindsey and the Filevine project email address, plus the recipient’s file note. The email, sent from Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022, asked, “Can you get me a receipt on the tax bill so I can get you reimbursed for that?”

Earlier that same day, Jeremy Lindsey replied to Aaron, adding Elizabeth “for visibility.” In his message, Jeremy apologized for missing Aaron’s call and expressed appreciation for help with paying the hospital bills. He confirmed that the information previously provided was accurate and that no additional medical services were being provided for any of them. Jeremy also noted that in addition to the medical bills, they had to pay a tax bill on the totaled vehicle amounting to $762.87. According to the county clerk, this tax was owed for 2025 because they possessed the car in the current year and it wasn’t officially totaled until January. He wasn’t sure if this tax could be recovered but wanted to bring it to Aaron’s attention. He acknowledged that the process could take a long time to close and that they simply wanted the medical bills paid so they would stop receiving calls. He thanked Aaron for the support since December and offered to help with anything else, signing the message, “Thanks, Jeremy,” and noting it was sent from Yahoo Mail for iPhone.

Earlier that afternoon, at 2:50 PM, Aaron Whaley had emailed Jeremy to confirm the outstanding bills he saw. He listed: $939.10 to UC for Elizabeth, $1,070.27 to Cincinnati Children’s for Chase, and $4,080.00 to Cincinnati Children’s for Owen. Aaron asked if these were all the outstanding bills and said he would have Auto Owners process them as soon as possible. He inquired whether there were any additional outstanding items and also asked for updates on medical treatment and follow-up visits. Specifically, he asked whether Owen had any follow-up visits after December 11, and noted that Chase’s last known visit was on April 2. The email concluded with Aaron’s contact information: Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Case Jeremy-Lindsey-MVA-12-01-2024 involves client Jeremy Lindsey following a motor vehicle accident.

Threshold for entitlement can be met in two ways: either the client has incurred at least $1,000 in medical bills, or the injury or disease is, in whole or in part, permanent disfigurement, a fracture to a bone (including compound, comminuted, displaced, or compressed fractures), loss of a body member, permanent injury within reasonable medical probability, permanent loss of bodily function, or death. Therefore, if the client has any scar from his laceration, that would qualify.
